bug.author: TKassis
bug.description:
<denchmark-h:h1>Summary</denchmark-h>
I'm loading a Tenserflow model which I would like to cache via @st.cache. I continually get the failed to hash object error even if I set allow_output_mutation=True. Whether it's True or False makes no difference to the error message. <denchmark-h:h1>Steps to reproduce</denchmark-h>
What are the steps we should take to reproduce the bug: <denchmark-link:https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/9168908/67726816-8ced2e00-f9bd-11e9-968e-586ac73f4e61.jpg></denchmark-link>
The below works fine, but is obviously slow since the model needs to be reloaded on every run: model = models.load_model(model_path, backbone_name='resnet50') <denchmark-h:h2>Expected behavior:</denchmark-h>
I expect that setting allow_output_mutation=True will allow me to cache the model without an error message. <denchmark-h:h2>Actual behavior:</denchmark-h>
I get the following: <denchmark-link:https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/9168908/67726709-1bad7b00-f9bd-11e9-8620-d4ad71d8fc4d.jpg></denchmark-link>
<denchmark-h:h2>Is this a regression?</denchmark-h>
No <denchmark-h:h1>Debug info</denchmark-h>
Streamlit version: 0.49.0 Python version: 3.6.7 Using a Conda environment OS version: Windows 10 Browser version: Chrome 78.0.3904.70
<denchmark-h:h1>Additional information</denchmark-h>
If needed, add any other context about the problem here.

comments.comment: Closing since st.cache behavior has changed significantly since this was filed. See use of in <denchmark-link:https://docs.streamlit.io/advanced_caching.html>https://docs.streamlit.io/advanced_caching.html</denchmark-link>
